thread_structure: Your mechanic lied to you about transmission flushes. Here's what they don't want you to know 🧵
Myth: You need a flush every 30k miles. Reality: Most manufacturers recommend 60k-100k or never.
Here's why shops push unnecessary flushes: $150-300 profit margin on a 20-minute service.
The REAL signs you need transmission service: slipping gears, delayed shifting, burnt smell, dark fluid.
Pro tip: Check your owner's manual. If it says 'lifetime fluid,' don't let anyone convince you otherwise.
Exception: Severe driving conditions (towing, mountains, city traffic) = more frequent changes needed.
Save this thread. Next time a shop recommends a flush, ask them to show you the dirty fluid first.

thread_structure: A customer just spent $6,500 on a transmission that could've been saved with a $200 fix. This is how it happened:
She noticed her car hesitating when shifting. Ignored it for 3 months because 'it wasn't that bad.'
That hesitation? Low transmission fluid from a leaking seal. $200 fix if caught early.
By month 3, the transmission was running dry. Metal-on-metal grinding destroyed internal components.
Now she needed a full rebuild. $6,500 + rental car costs while we worked on it.
The lesson: Small symptoms = small bills. Ignored symptoms = catastrophic failures.
If your transmission does ANYTHING unusual, get it checked immediately. I've never seen someone regret being proactive.

thread_structure: Saw a YouTube video on 'easy transmission repair'? Here's why you should NOT attempt this yourself:
Transmissions have 300+ internal parts. One misplaced washer = complete failure.
Special tools required: seal pullers, clutch compressors, dial indicators. $2,000+ in equipment.
Diagnostic skills: You need to know EXACTLY what failed before opening it up.
Reassembly torque specs are critical. Over-torque by 5 ft-lbs? You just cracked your case.
That said: Fluid changes? Do it yourself. External seal repairs? Maybe. Internal work? Please don't.
I fix DIY transmission jobs weekly. They always cost 2-3x more than if they'd brought it in first.

thread_structure: If you own a Ford with a 10R80 transmission, read this thread. It could save you thousands.
The 10R80 (2017+ F150, Mustang, Expedition) is actually a GREAT transmission... with one fatal flaw.
The torque converter can shudder between 30-50 mph. Feels like driving on rumble strips.
Ford's fix: Fluid change with new Mercon ULV fluid + additives. $300 service fixes 80% of cases.
If ignored, the shuddering wears clutch material, contaminating fluid, leading to $4k+ rebuild.
If you feel ANY vibration at low speeds, get the fluid serviced immediately. Don't wait.
This is covered under powertrain warranty if under 60k miles. After that, you're paying out of pocket.

thread_structure: Winter is coming. Your transmission needs prep work too. Here's your cold weather checklist:
1. Check fluid level when COLD. Transmissions use more fluid in winter, low levels cause shifting issues.
2. Let your car idle for 60 seconds before driving. Thick cold fluid needs time to circulate.
3. Avoid aggressive driving for first 5 minutes. Let transmission warm up gradually.
4. If you're in extreme cold (below 0°F), consider synthetic transmission fluid. Flows better when cold.
5. Watch for delayed engagement (shift lag when cold). Normal for first shift, but persistent lag = problem.
Do this now, avoid being stranded in February. Your transmission will thank you.
